Damaged Building
Dismantling
Builders must be <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">assigned</style></link> for any Building except <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Fields and Orchards</style></link>.

Construction of a Building is commissioned by specifying a construction site on the ground of the targeted location. When the Soil does not permit the Building to be built, the areas with problems are marked in red. Any construction site can be configured, even when the settlement doesn't have the necessary Resources yet.
If the Soil is <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">contaminated</style></link> with Radiation, the Settlers begin by digging up the Soil first.
As soon as the Settlers have freed the construction site from Radiation, Builders will bring the Resources necessary for Construction to the construction site. 
When all the Resources needed are there the Builders will begin to construct the Building.

Many Buildings have a fixed working radius. <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">Employed</style></link> Settlers who work on the Building only work within this assigned radius. You can shift the radius using the appropriate icon.

Entrances to Buildings are marked as a green area.
Settlers can enter and exit the Building solely at these entrances.
Any Building can be rotated. The Building will then be rotated 90° clockwise.

Roads are created differently than Buildings. Choose a point on the ground where you want to place a Road. Now drag the Road along the route the Road is supposed to take.
Once you have finished that your Builders can start laying out the Road.
Your Builders begin to dismantle the Streets in the selected area.

<link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Fields and Orchards</style></link> are built differently than Buildings.
Choose a point on the ground where you want to create a Field. Now drag to enlarge the Field until it has reached the desired size. 
The minimum size for a Field or an Orchard is 6x6, the maximum size is 16x16.

On a construction site you can indicate that the site is supposed to receive priority.
Your Builders will focus on constructing this Building.
Your Builders are going to interrupt the Building's construction process. No Resources are brought to the construction site during a construction pause.
Your Builders stop construction of the Building completely, and all Resources already brought to the construction site are brought back to the Warehouse.

Buildings become damaged when they have been caught in a <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">sandstorm</style></link>.
A Building that has sustained too much damage becomes inactive until it is repaired.
Settlers who have to live in damaged Houses lose some <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>. Your Builders automatically repair all damaged Buildings.
Your Builders can take readily constructed Buildings apart again. A small part of the Resources used to construct the Building can be used again and is brought to the Warehouse.

Paved Paths are constructed the same way as commonplace gravel paths. Settlers are able to move faster on Paved Paths than on gravel paths. To be able to construct Paved Paths, the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.
Using Tasks
Tasks
Gather Wood
Gather Scrap
Gather Plants
Gather Everything
Remove Radiation
Cancel Remove Radiation

With the help of Tasks, <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">freely available Settlers</style></link> are instructed to gather certain Resources or remove Radiation in a certain area. Tasks like these will only be performed by Settlers who do not perform <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">any function</style></link>. Up to 4 Settlers can work on one Task at the same time. The only exception to this is the Task for removing Radiation. The Task to remove Radiation will be carried out by any Settler who currently has nothing to do, even by those Settlers who have been assigned a Profession.

Settlers begin gathering <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Wood</style></link> from <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">trees</style></link> located within the <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">active working area</style></link>.

Settlers begin by collecting <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Scrap</style></link> from <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Scrap Piles</style></link> located within the <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">active working area</style></link>. However, they cannot collect any Scrap from <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">large Ruins</style></link>. To have them do this they must be <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">assigned</style></link> as <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Scrap Collectors</style></link>.

Settlers begin gathering <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Berries, Mushrooms</style></link> and <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">Herbs</style></link> located within the <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">active working area</style></link>.
Settlers begin to gather all Resources located within the Task's <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">active working area</style></link>.

Settlers begin to remove <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation pollution</style></link> by digging up the soil. 
Unlike other Tasks, here you don’t need any <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">freely available Settlers</style></link>. All Settlers who have nothing to do at the moment, even those who have a Workplace, will help dig.
Settlers will stop removing <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation</style></link> from the selected area.
Professions
Assignment of a Profession
Adjusting Settlers Working at a Building
Freely Available Settlers
Employed Settlers

Individual Settlers cannot be employed directly. Instead the number of Settlers practicing a certain Profession can be set manually. On the basis of this allocation Settlers are automatically chosen and assigned to the respective Profession.
The number of employed Settlers who work at a specific Workplace can be adjusted manually. This is limited by the maximum number of Workers for each type of Building or Task.

Settlers who have not been assigned any Profession do not remain idle.
They transport Resources to Depots, Warehouses and storage sites and clean up radioactive contamination from <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction sites</style></link>. They clear away trees and Scrap Ruins, too. 
They also carry out all  <link="2"><style="DefaultLink">Tasks</style></link> assigned to them.
When a Settler with an assigned Profession dies, a freely available Settler is automatically assigned this Profession.

Allocated Settlers work in the Profession issued to them.
They will not carry out any <link="2"><style="DefaultLink">Tasks</style></link> that are created separately.
If for some reason they are unable to perform their work, they will not be idle.
They will begin to bring Resources to <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction sites</style></link> and into Warehouses. Additionally, they also remove Radiation from active working areas of the <link="2"><style="DefaultLink">Remove Radiation</style></link> Task.
Hunger
Hungry Settlers
Forest Plants
Wild Game
Seedlings
Processed Food

Settlers need Food to survive. If they are not supplied with enough Food they starve and die. The more <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">sources of Food</style></link> available to them, the better. If Settlers are hungry and Food is available, they attend to their nutrition self-reliantly.

Forest Plants grow near <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">trees</style></link>. They regrow when the <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Irrigation Level</style></link> is sufficient. In the same vein, they wither away when the soil is too dry.
They can be gathered up via the respective <link="2"><style="DefaultLink">Task</style></link> or by Gatherers.

The Gatherer's Cabin <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Gatherers. Gatherers pick Mushrooms and Berries that lie within <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">their working radius</style></link>. Gatherers work more efficiently when the Gatherer's Cabin is <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">placed</style></link> in the vicinity of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">trees</style></link>.

Wild Game roams the map in herds. It can be hunted by Hunters.
Wild Game needs time to reproduce, and overhunting will impair the speed of reproduction. In addition, Wild Game can be captured by Hunters and kept on Pastures.

The Hunting Lodge <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Hunters. Hunters hunt Wild Animals in their <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">working area</style></link>. This working area ought to be regularly adapted to the position of Wild Animals on the map. In addition, Hunters can also be instructed to capture Wild Animals so that they can be kept on a Pasture.

The Fishing Hut <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Fishermen. The Fishermen catch fish from <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Lakes</style></link>.
A Fishing Hut must be <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">placed</style></link> next to a sufficiently large Lake. 
Placing many Fishing Huts next to each other reduces their productivity. That's why they should be placed outside the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">working areas</style></link> of neighboring Fishing Huts.

There are many different Seeds with which Fields can be planted and Orchards can be sown. All of the Plants have individual Growing Times and Yields. Employed Farmers plant Seeds and bring in the Crops.
Plants grow faster when the <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Irrigation Level</style></link> is sufficiently high.
If the soil dries out, the Plants dry up too and die.

Fields <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employ</style></link> Farmers. Farmers plant and harvest Crops when Fields are ready to be harvested. The type of Seed to be sown can be chosen.
Other types of Seeds can also be put on the waiting list. The Farmers begin cultivating the new Seed as soon as the current Crop has been harvested. To plant the new Seed immediately, the current Crop can also be harvested right away instead.

Orchards operate similarly to Fields and <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employ</style></link> Farmers.
Unlike Crops in Field cultivation, Seeds from Orchards spawn Fruit or Nut trees.
Trees have an initial Growing Time before they yield a Crop. Once an Orchard tree has grown, Farmers can bring in Harvests from it for several Seasons before the tree has to be replanted.
Rich Food is made from Food. Settlers can consume Rich Food the same way they consume normal Food in order to satisfy their Hunger.

The Kitchen <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Cooks. Cooks produce Rich Food from Food. To be able to build a Kitchen, the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

The Pasture <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Herders. Herders take care of the grazing Animals kept on the Pasture. To be able to assign a captured Wild Animal to a certain Pasture the button "Choose next Animal" must be selected on that Pasture. Wild Animals being kept on a Pasture must be supplied with Water so that they don't perish. When a Herder takes care of the Animals they will reproduce and grow. As soon as enough Animals are fully grown they can be slaughtered. Some Animals produce additional valuable Resources such as Milk or Eggs.
Greenhouse

The Greenhouse <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Farmers. All the Seeds that can be sown on Fields can be planted in a Greenhouse. As long as the Plants are supplied with sufficient <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link> they grow automatically and do not have to be sown again. Inside the Greenhouse the Plants are protected against <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">environmental Radiation</style></link> as well as Radiation from stockpiled Water, and they grow faster than on a Cultivated Field. To be able to build a Greenhouse the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.
Aquafarm

The Aquafarm <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Fishermen. Fish grow continuously there as long as the Aquafarm is supplied with sufficient <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. These Fish are protected against <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">environmental Radiation</style></link> as well as Radiation from stockpiled Water. They can also be bred during a <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Drought</style></link>. To be able to build an Aquafarm the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.
Milk
Milk is produced on Pastures when Buffalos or Goats are kept there. Milk serves as a source of Food and is needed to manufacture <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">Soap</style></link>.
Thirst
Thirsty Settlers
Lakes

Settlers require Water to survive. If they are not supplied with enough Water they die of thirst. The more sources of Water available to them, the better. When Settlers get thirsty and Water is available, they will take care of their nutrition themselves.

The Cistern <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Water Carriers. These Water Carriers collect Water from all available sources of Water within the active <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">working area</style></link>. One Cistern can <link="18"><style="DefaultLink">store</style></link> up to 2000 units of Water. From which sources the Cisterns ought to collect Water can be set manually.

The Water Tower works similarly to the Cisterns and represents an upgrade. A single Water Tower can <link="18"><style="DefaultLink">store</style></link> up to 5000 units of Water. The maximum number of Water Carriers is accordingly higher. In addition, the Water Tower has a filtration system to filter out the Radiation from <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">contaminated water</style></link> using <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link>.

Lakes are the primary source of Water for the settlement. Water can be collected there with the help of a Jetty. In addition, Lakes allow <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Fishing Huts</style></link> to gather Food.
Special attention should always be paid to the Lake's <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link> because Water Carriers collect Water contaminated with Radiation, too. All Lakes dry up temporarily during a <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Drought</style></link>. This source of Water runs dry as a result.
The Jetty creates a point at which Water Carriers can collect Water from a Lake.

Wells <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employ</style></link> Wellkeepers. Wellkeepers pump groundwater into a retention basin.
This Water can subsequently be collected by Water Carriers and brought to Water Towers or Cisterns. 
Placing multiple Wells next to each other or next to Electric Pumps reduces their productivity.

The Rainwater Collector collects Water from <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">rain clouds</style></link>. This Water is picked up by Water Carriers and brought to a Water Tower or a Cistern. Attention absolutely ought to be paid to the rain clouds' <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link> because Rainwater Collectors also capture rain contaminated by Radiation. The <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Rainwater Collector is temporarily coverable</style></link> to prevent this.

The Electric Pump conveys Water on its own. However, it must have <link="13"><style="DefaultLink">Electricity</style></link> to be able to function. This conveyed Water is picked up by Water Carriers and brought to Water Towers or Cisterns.
Placing multiple Electric Pumps next to each other or next to Wells decreases their Productivity. As a result they ought to be placed outside any neighboring <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">working areas</style></link>.
Pumping Station

A Pumping Station consumes <link="13"><style="DefaultLink">Electricity</style></link> to continuously convey Water from a Lake and can pump the Water into Upgraded Water Towers. No additional <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">Workforce</style></link> is required to do this. To be able to build a Pumping Station the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.
Upgraded Water Tower

The Upgraded Water Tower works similarly to the way the Water Tower and the Cistern work. As the name says, it represents an upgrade. One single Upgraded Water Tower can <link="18"><style="DefaultLink">stockpile</style></link> up to 20,000 units of Water. The maximum number of Water Carriers is equally higher. In addition, the Water Tower has a filtration system to cleanse Radiation from <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">contaminated Water</style></link> with the help of <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link>. What’s more, the Upgraded Water Tower can be hooked up to a Pumping Station in order to be automatically refilled with Water. To be able to build an Upgraded Water Tower the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.
Weather
Weather
Day/Night Cycle
Rain
Irrigation
Water Heat Map
Contaminated Rain
Drought
Sandstorm
The weather influences Settlers' lives to a great extent. It should be constantly checked which kind of weather awaits the settlement in the coming Seasons and prepare accordingly.
During the night all production Buildings work at a slower pace. If they are supplied with <link="13"><style="DefaultLink">Electricity</style></link> they work more efficiently.

Rain clouds move across the map and increase the Irrigation Level of the soil beneath them. Some clouds bring "acid rain". On the other hand, rain not contaminated with Radiation decreases the <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link> of the soil.

The Irrigation Level indicates the <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water Level</style></link> of the soil. The more Water stored in the soil, the faster Plants like <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Berries, Mushrooms and Seedlings</style></link> grow on it. If the soil is dried out, the Plants wither away and die, too.
Soil moisture can be made visible by switching on the Water Analysis Heat Map.

Contaminated rain increases the <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link> in the soil. There are three kinds of contaminated rain. Each type of rain pushes the Radiation Level to its respective value. Acid rain increases the Irrigation Level of the soil just like normal rain.

During a drought the soil dries out and <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Plants as well as Seedlings</style></link> wither away.
All <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Lakes</style></link> dry up at the same time. Water returns to the Lakes at the end of a drought.

Some droughts are accompanied by a sandstorm. The sandstorm influences the <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link> of the soil. Settlers caught in a sandstorm move slower. 
Any Building hit by a sandstorm will also be <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">damaged</style></link> and (if not repaired) eventually become unusable.

The Weather Station displays the Radiation Level of current and future rain clouds.
At which point <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Cultivated Fields</style></link> or <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Rainwater Collectors</style></link> ought to be covered so that they are spared from contaminated rain can also be set here. To be able to build a Weather Station the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

The Irrigation Plant <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Irrigators. 
The Irrigator transports Water from the <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water Tower</style></link> or the Cistern to the Plant System.
Once activated, the Plant System increases the Irrigation Level of the soil in the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">working area</style></link>.
The higher the Irrigation Level is supposed to be, the more Water is going to be consumed during Irrigation. During a drought the Irrigation Plant System consumes even more Water.
If the Water is contaminated with Radiation, the <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link> in the Plant System working area increases as well.
In turn, Water not contaminated with Radiation reduces the Radiation Level.
Confidence
Settlers' Confidence
Total Confidence

The Total Confidence of the settlement displays the average Contentedness of the Settlers. The lower the Total Contentedness of the settlement, the more likely it will be that the Settlers complain about their situation. It can even get to the point where they make their displeasure known and rebellions or exoduses occur. At a high level of Contentedness Settlers work faster and more effectively. That's why an eye should always be kept on the Total Contentedness of the Population.

Many different factors influence Settlers' Confidence. Discontented Settlers need longer <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">to reproduce</style></link>. The time periods for <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> and Production increase as well. For Settlers with an especially low level of Confidence, the speed of walking is reduced. In contrast, contented Settlers <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">reproduce</style></link> faster and live longer. With happy Settlers, the time periods for Research and Production are shortened. For Settlers with an especially high level of Confidence, the speed of walking is increased.

Settlers can visit a Campfire and spend some time there in order to temporarily strengthen their Confidence. The Campfire increases the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

The Cemetery <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Morticians. Morticians gather up dead Settlers located within their <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">assigned working area</style></link>. The dead Settlers are buried at the Cemetery when enough graves exist. Graves are usable again over the course of time. 
If a Settler has a dead relative who is not lying in a grave, he/she receives a debuff to his/her Confidence. Settlers can also visit their relatives' graves to temporarily boost their Confidence.

Hard Liquor can be produced by a Pubkeeper from <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Fruit</style></link>. Hard Liquor temporarily boosts the Confidence of those who consume it and reduces their <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Thirst</style></link>.

Beer can be made by an Pubkeeper out of <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link> and <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Wheat</style></link>.
Consuming it not only provides a temporary boost to Settlers' Confidence, it also reduces <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">thirst</style></link>.
Hemp can be planted on <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Fields</style></link> and behaves like any other Seed. It can be used later on to produce Joints or Cloth.
Joints can made by an Pubkeeper out of Hemp.

The Pub <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> a Pubkeeper. Pubkeepers produce Beer, Hard Liquor or Joints from different ingredients. Each Pubkeeper is only able to make one of these products at a time.
Which product is supposed to be produced next can be set. The employed Pubkeeper begins with the work on the new product as soon as the current Task is completed.
Settlers can visit the Pub. If they are provided with Beer, Hard Liquor or Joints they get a temporary boost to their Confidence.
Coffee Beans
Just like any Seed, Coffee Beans are planted on <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Cultivated Fields</style></link>. Later on they can be used to produce Coffee.
Coffee

Coffee can be produced by a Pubkeeper from <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link> and Coffee Beans.
This temporarily increases the Confidence of its consumers and reduces their <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Thirst</style></link>.
Upgraded Pub

The Upgraded Pub employs Pubkeepers. The Upgraded Pub employs more Pubkeepers than the normal Pub. The Pubkeepers produce Beer, Hard Liquor, Coffee or Joints from various ingredients and are somewhat more efficient than the output in a normal Pub. Each Pubkeeper can only make one of these Products at a time.
Which Product ought to be produced next can be configured. The employed Pubkeeper begins with the work on the new Product as soon as the current Task has been finished.
Settlers can visit the Pub. They receive a temporary boost in Confidence when they are provided with Beer, Hard Liquor, Coffee or Joints.
Health
Settlers' Health
Illnesses
Iodine Tablets

Health is crucial for the survival of Settlers.
When the Settlers' Health status is poor and Herbs or Medicine are available they take care of healthcare themselves. Providing a large amount of different <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Food sources</style></link> keeps Settlers healthy. <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">High-level Radiation</style></link> diminishes their Health. In the case of Settlers with low-level Health, they move slower and run a greater risk of getting sick.

Herbs grow near <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">trees</style></link>. They regrow when the <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Irrigation Level</style></link> of the soil is sufficiently high. In turn, when the soil is arid they wither. They can be gathered either via the <link="2"><style="DefaultLink">Gather Plants Task</style></link> or by Herbalists.

The Herbal Hut <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Herbalists. Herbalists gather Herbs located within their <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">assigned working area</style></link>. Herbalists work more efficiently when the Herbal Hut lies in the vicinity of some <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">trees</style></link>.

Medicine is made by medical doctors out of Herbs.
It increases your Settlers' Health far more effectively than Herbs.

The Medical Facility <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Medics.
It stores Herbs and processes them into Medicine.
If an Illness breaks out in your settlement, Settlers go to the nearest Medical Facility to receive treatment, provided that sufficient space exists at the Facility.

An Illness might break out in your settlement from time to time.
Settlers infected with such an illness go to the nearest Medical Facility for treatment. If they are not treated, an illness can cause the death of your Settlers.
The possibility exists for Settlers to infect other Settlers while passing by them.
Iodine Tablets are made by Medics out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Iodine</style></link>. These tablets lower the Settlers' <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link>.
Soap

Soap is manufactured by Doctors out of Herbs and <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Milk</style></link>. It increases the <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link> and Health of the Settlers who use it. To be able to produce Soap the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.
Radiation
Radiation
Terrestrial Radiation
Settlers' Radiation Contamination
Radioactively Contaminated Food
Radioactively Contaminated Water

Radiation is one of the most prominent threats to the settlement. Whenever possible, Settlers should not be exposed to any High-level Radiation. Radiation exists at different levels. These levels range from No Radiation to High-level Radiation.
Low-level Radiation is generally depicted in green, Medium-level Radiation in yellow, and High-level Radiation in red. The higher the level of Radiation, the more dangerous it is.
Toggling to the Radiation Heat Map makes the current level of Terrestrial Radiation visible. This enables an eye to be kept on the surroundings and contaminated areas avoided.

When Settlers are exposed to Radiation from any source, their individual Radiation Exposure Level rises.
In the case of higher-level Radiation, the Settlers' <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">Health</style></link> declines much faster, making them more susceptible to <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">Illness</style></link>. If a Settler's Radiation Exposure Level rises too high, the Settler eventually becomes infertile and can even die from the Radiation.

Food Items harvested from soil contaminated with Radiation are equally contaminated.
If Settlers consume such <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Food Items</style></link> their Radiation Exposure Level rises.

<link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link> is contaminated when it is collected from a Lake or a Rainwater Collector containing Water contaminated with Radiation. If Settlers consume these kinds of Water their Radiation Exposure Level rises.
Radiation Protection
Radiation Protection Clothing
Allocation of Radiation Protection Clothing
Decontamination Kit

Settlers need clothing to protect themselves against omnipresent <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation</style></link>.
When Settlers have no Protective Clothing but clothing is available they equip themselves on their own. Better clothing protects against higher-level Radiation.
Protective clothing becomes unusable over time and must be replaced.

Neck Scarves fully protect Settlers against <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Low-level Radiation</style></link>. Neck Scarves also provide a slight amount of protection against higher-level Radiation, but they do not shield against it completely. They are made by Tailors and require <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Cloth</style></link>.

Activated Carbon Masks fully protect Settlers against <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Low- and Medium-level Radiation</style></link>. Activated Carbon Masks also provide a slight amount of protection against higher-level Radiation, but they do not shield against it completely. They are made by Tailors and require <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Cloth</style></link> and Coal.

Radiation Suits fully protect Settlers against <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Low-, Medium- and High-level Radiation</style></link>. They are made by Tailors and require <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Cloth</style></link>, Coal and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Plastic</style></link>.

The Tailor's Shop <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Tailors. Tailors make Neck Scarves, Activated Carbon Masks and Radiation Suits out of <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Cloth</style></link>, Coal and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Plastic</style></link>. It can be specified which of the 3 products is supposed to be produced next. The employed Tailors begin with the work on the new product as soon as the current Task is completed. The Tailor's Shop reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

Coal is produced by the Charcoal Burner. <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Wood</style></link> is needed to produce it.
Coal can be used to make Protective Clothing or to filter the Water stored in <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water Towers</style></link>.

The Charcoal Kiln <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Charcoal Burners. Charcoal Burners make Charcoal out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Wood</style></link>. The Charcoal Kiln reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

Which type of Protective Clothing is going to be issued to Settlers is specified at the Town Center. Settlers equip themselves only with the type of Protective Clothing that has been permitted for them.

Decontamination Kits are produced at Decontamination Posts and distributed by Decontaminators to all Buildings that stockpile <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">Food</style></link>. A Decontamination Kit can remove up to 600 units of <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation</style></link> from Food.

The Decontamination Post <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Decontaminators. Decontaminators produce Decontamination Kits. Decontaminators distribute Decontamination Kits to all Buildings that stockpile <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">Food</style></link> which are located within the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">working area</style></link> of a given Decontamination Post.

The Upgraded Tailor's Shop <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link>Tailors. Tailors produce Neck Scarves, Activated Carbon Masks and Radiation Suits out of <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Cloth</style></link>, Coal and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Plastic</style></link>. It can be specified which of the 3 products is supposed to be produced next. The employed Tailors start the work on the new product as soon as the current Task is completed. The Upgraded Tailor's Shop reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity. To be able to build an Upgraded Tailor's Shop the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.
Tools
Tools

Tools help Settlers in the course of all Tasks. When Settlers have no Tools and Tools are available they equip themselves on their own.
Settlers who own Tools produce Resources faster with each Task. They can also increase the chance of an Expedition's success. Tools lose durability each time they are used. When a Tool has no durability anymore the Settler needs a new one.

Scrap Tools increase the production speed in the case of Tasks where the Settler is equipped with them. Scrap tools are made in the Workshop out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Wood and Scrap</style></link>.

Metal Tools substantially increase the production speed in the case of Tasks where the Settler is equipped with them. Metal Tools are made in the Workshop out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Wood, Scrap</style></link> and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Metal</style></link>.

The Workshop <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Technicians. Technicians make Scrap Tools or Metal Tools out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Wood, Scrap</style></link> or <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Metal</style></link>. Which product is supposed to be produced next can be set. The employed Technician begins with the work on the new product as soon as the current Task is completed. The Workshop reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

The Upgraded Workshop <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Technicians. Technicians produce Scrap Tools or Metal Tools out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Wood, Scrap</style></link> or <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Metal</style></link>. The Upgraded Workshop works more effectively than the normal Workshop. Which product is supposed to be produced next can be set. The employed Technician starts the work on the new product as soon as the current Task is completed. The Upgraded Workshop reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity. To be able to build an Upgraded Workshop the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.
Electricity
Electricity
Power Grid

A Building is supplied with Electricity by hooking it up to a Power Grid. If a Building is connected to the Power Grid,  the working hours decrease during <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">daytime as well as nighttime</style></link>. Each Building that is supplied with Electricity this way consumes a certain amount of the total Power Supply for as long as it is connected.

The Power Supply of Buildings hooked up to the Power Grid can be manually enabled or disabled. As long as sufficient Electricity is not available, none of the Buildings in the affected Power Grid will be supplied. When a Cabin, Sturdy House or Upgraded Shelter is hooked up to the Power Grid and being supplied, the Inhabitants additionally get a boost to their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>.

The Solar Collector generates Power during the <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Daytime</style></link>. No energy is generated at night. To be able to build a Solar Collector, the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

A Battery can store surplus Electricity until it is fully charged. In the <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Nighttime</style></link> this Electricity is used to supply all connected Buildings with energy until the Battery is empty. To be able to construct a Battery the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first. The Battery reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.
Power Lines connect Buildings to the Power Grid.

The Wind Turbine continuously generates a small amount of Electricity. To be able to build a Wind Turbine the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first. The Wind Turbine reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.
Expeditions
Expeditions to Ruins
Scouting Ruins
Sending Off an Expedition
Advantages
Expedition Rations

Some of the older Ruins in the region could still contain valuable Resources like <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Plastic, Metal</style></link> or similar items. It's possible that <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">new Seeds for Fields and Orchards</style></link> might also be found among the Resources. In order to search for valuable things in the Ruins the sites first have to be scouted out and explored, then they are subsequently visited by an Expedition. Once everything of value has been found inside a Ruin, <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Scrap Collectors</style></link> can <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">strip the Ruins</style></link> just like normal ones.

Scouts can be sent to certain Ruins to unlock them for future Expeditions.
A Scout will visit the Ruin and then return with more precise information about it.
This information also includes the types of Advantages that might be helpful during the Expedition.

Once a Ruin has been scouted out, some Settlers can visit it within the framework of an Expedition. Which Settlers take part in an Expedition must be specified beforehand. In the course of preparations attention ought to be paid to specific Advantages and the provision with sufficient Rations.

Advantages hold sway over an Expedition's prospects for success. Some of these Advantages vary a great deal and depend on the respective Ruin. Previously sent out Scouts provide information about which Advantages are helpful for the Expedition.

Sending Settlers off on an Expedition takes place together with Rations. These Rations consist of <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link> and <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Food</style></link>.
All Explorers need Rations for the journey to the Ruin. They use up additional Rations whenever they complete a Task during an Expedition.

The Expedition Station <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Scouts. Scouts produce Rations and can be sent to scout out Ruins. Expeditions are started from an Expedition Station, too. Only one Expedition Station can be built.
Accumulating Resources
Scrap Piles
Scrap Ruins
Trees
Iodine
Mine

Scrap is one of the key Resources for the settlement.
Many Buildings require Scrap in order to be <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">built</style></link>. It is also needed to obtain <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">refined Resources such as Cloth</style></link> and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Plastic</style></link>, and to make <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Tools</style></link>.

Scrap Piles contain a varying amount of Scrap, depending on their size.
Scrap Piles can be amassed either via the <link="2"><style="DefaultLink">Gather Up Scrap Task</style></link> or by Scrap Collectors.
Scrap Ruins contain larger amounts of Scrap. They can only be taken apart by Scrap Collectors.

The Scrapyard <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Scrap Collectors. Scrap Collectors collect the Scrap located within their <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">assigned working area</style></link>. Scrap Collectors work more efficiently when the Scrapyard is placed <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">in the vicinity</style></link> of several Scrap Piles or Scrap Ruins. The Scrapyard reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

Wood is one of the key Resources for the settlement.
Many Buildings require Wood for their <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction</style></link>. It is also needed to make <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link> and for making <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Tools</style></link>.

Trees grow everywhere on the Map. Depending on their size and age, they supply a certain amount of Wood.
They can be chopped down, either with the help of the <link="2"><style="DefaultLink">Gather Wood Task</style></link> or by Foresters.
If the <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Irrigation Level</style></link> is sufficient, <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">Mushrooms and Berries</style></link> begin to grow near them.
Foresters can reforest cleared areas.

The Forester Lodge <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Foresters. Foresters collect Wood located within their <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">assigned working area</style></link>. Foresters work more efficiently when the Forester Lodger is erected in the vicinity of some <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">trees</style></link>. Foresters can equally plant new trees. The Forester Lodge can be set so that it chops down or plants trees, or performs both at the same time. The Forester Lodge reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

The Scrap Catcher catches pieces of Scrap that fly around. Over time this generates accumulated <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Scrap</style></link> that can be collected by Scrap Collectors. The quantity of caught Scrap increases enormously during a <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Sandstorm</style></link>. To be able to construct a Scrap Catcher, the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

Iodine is recovered in Mines. It can be processed into Iodine Tablets at a <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">Medical Facility</style></link>. These tablets are able to lower Settlers' <link="10"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Level</style></link>.

The Mine <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Miners. Mines can extract either Iodine, Sulfur or <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link>. Which Resource is supposed to be produced next can be configured. The assigned Miners begin with the work on the new Resource as soon as the current Mission has been completed. Placing many Mines next to each other reduces their Productivity. That's why they ought to be kept outside the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">working areas</style></link> of neighboring Mines. To be able to build a Mine the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first. The Mine reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> near the Mine.
Sand

Sand is needed to manufacture <link="25"><style="DefaultLink">Glass</style></link> or <link="25"><style="DefaultLink">Concrete</style></link>. It can be extracted from a <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Lake</style></link> by a Sand Mine.
Sand Mine

The Sand Mine <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Miners. These Miners extract Sand from <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Lakes</style></link>. To do this they must be placed directly next to a Lake. To be able to build a Sand Mine the approriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.
Cement
Cement is mined in Mines. It is needed to produce <link="25"><style="DefaultLink">Concrete</style></link>.
Sorting Scrap
Sorting Scrap

Refined Resources are needed for the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction</style></link> of Buildings, but also for the Production of <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Protective Clothing</style></link> or <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Metal Tools</style></link>.
These Resources are manufactured from <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Scrap</style></link>.

Cloth is used in the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction</style></link> of certain Buildings such as the <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Tailor's Shop</style></link> or the <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">Shelter</style></link>.
It is also a crucial component for manufacturing <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Protective Clothing</style></link>.

Metal is used in the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction</style></link> of certain Buildings such as the <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Expedition Station</style></link> or the <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Workshop</style></link>.
It is also a crucial component for making <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Metal Tools</style></link>.

Plastic is used in the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction</style></link> of certain Buildings such as <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Rainwater Collectors</style></link> or the <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">Irrigation Plant</style></link>.
It is also a crucial component of <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Radiation Suits</style></link>.

Electronics are used above all in the <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">construction</style></link> of <link="13"><style="DefaultLink">Electricity Buildings</style></link> or special Buildings such as the <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">Medical Facility</style></link>.

The Recycler <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Refiners. Recyclers produce refined Resources from <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Scrap</style></link>. 
Each Refiner can only produce one of these Resources at a time. 
Which Resource is supposed to be produced next can be set. The assigned Refiner begins with the work on the new Resource as soon as the current Task is completed. The Recycler reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

The Refinery functions similar to the way the Recycler works and equally <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Refiners. Unlike the Recycler, a Refinery produces all refined Resources at the same time. It cycles each Resource through automatically. The Refinery is able to utilize a larger number of Refiners and requires less time for the Production of each individual Resource. To be able to build a Refinery the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first. The Refinery reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

The Hemp Weaving Mill <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Tailors. Weaving Mills produce Cloth made of Hemp. To be able to build a Hemp Weaving Mill, the appropriate  <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.
Education
Education

Educated Settlers complete every Task assigned to them faster than Uneducated Settlers.
Educated Settlers are also able to utilize their <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Tools</style></link> and <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Protective Clothing</style></link> more effectively.
Their Tools and protective clothing last twice as long. 
The more settlers who are educated, the more efficiently your settlement will function. To be regarded as educated, the settler must have gone to school during his/her childhood.
The School <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Teachers. As long as sufficient space is available and a Teacher is present, Children will attend school and get educated.
Education
Education
School
Advanced School

Educated Settlers complete their Tasks faster and receive more Badges than Uneducated Settlers. Educated Settlers also use their <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Tools</style></link> and <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Protective Clothing</style></link> more effectively so that they last twice as long. Each Settler is trained individually in these areas. The better the Settler is in an area, the more effective the Settler is going to be in it. The greater the number of Settlers who receive training, the more efficiently a settlement is going to function. To be considered Educated the Settler must have attended a School during their childhood.

The School <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Teachers. As long as sufficient space is available and a Teacher is present, the Children will go to the School and be educated. Children who attend a School are educated in all subjects. However, they will be educated particularly well in one subject. A School can change its focus on a subject at any time.

The Upgraded School <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Teachers. Children will attend the Upgraded School for their educational training as long as sufficient space is available and a Teacher is present. In contrast to the School, the Upgraded School has no focus on a certain subject area. Children at the Upgraded School are educated in all areas to the best possible extent. To be able to build an Upgraded School the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.
Storage
Storage
Building Storage
Settler Inventory
Production Limits
Town Center Depot
Town Center Upgrade
First Upgrade Phase
Second Upgrade Phase

Each Resource must be stored so that it can be redistributed by the Settlers.
Settlers stockpile Resources automatically when sufficient Storage Capacity exists.
Each Resource has an individual weight and therefore uses up varying amounts of Storage Capacity.

Not all Buildings can store every Resource. Most Buildings can only store the Resources they produce or need for their own production. Settlers bring and take these Resources into or out of the Building on their own.

Settlers have their own Inventory. A Settler is able to collect Resources until his/her Inventory space has reached its capacity. The number of different types of Resources plays no role in the Inventory.

A Production Limit can be specified for each Resource. The settlement stops producing a certain Resource when the Production Limit is reached. Settlers start production again as soon as the Resource quantity has fallen below the Production Limit.
The Town Center can store any Resource except <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. Which types of Resources are supposed to be stored in the Town Center can be set at any time.

A Temporary Storeroom can store any Resource except <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. Which types of Resources are supposed to be stored in the Temporary Storeroom can be set at any time. The Temporary Storeroom can be upgraded up to two times. The Building's Storage Capacity increases with each upgrade phase.

The Market employs Logisticians. Logisticians gather Resources from all Warehouses and Storage Buildings and bring them to the Market. The Market also has a Depot for <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. Settlers who visit the Market get a temporary boost to their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>. The types of Resources that are supposed to be stored at the Market can be set at any time. The Market increases the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

The Market employs Logisticians. Logisticians accumulate Resources from all Warehouses and Storage Buildings and bring them to the Market. The Market also has a Depot for <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. Logisticians start off from the Market to supply Production Buildings with the given Resources they need to work. As a result, the Specialists who work at  Production facilities don't have to acquire raw Materials themselves and can focus on producing as effectively as possible.
The Town Center can be upgraded up to two times. Each upgrade increases the Town Center's Storage Capacity.

In addition to increasing Storage Capacity, Settlers can visit an upgraded Town Center in order to increase their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>. This increase in Confidence functions the same way as a <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Campfire</style></link>.

If the Town Center is upgraded a second time, Storage Capacity increases a second time, too. In addition, at this point the Town Center is able to pick up radio messages from other survivors. Furthermore, Settlers can visit the Town Center to increase their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>.

A Warehouse can store any Resource except <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. Which types of Resources are supposed to be stored at a Warehouse can be set at any time. The Warehouse can be upgraded once to increase the Building's Storage Capacity. To be able to build a Warehouse the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

An Upgraded Warehouse can store any Resource except <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. Which types of Resources are supposed to be stored at an Upgraded Warehouse can be set at any time. To be able to build an Upgraded Warehouse the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

The Food Station <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Logisticians. Logisticians transport Food from the settlement's Storage Buildings and Production facilities to the Food Station. The Food can subsequently be consumed here by Settlers. The Food Station can be instructed to stockpile only unprocessed Food, only processed Food or all types of Food.

The Water Point <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Logisticians. Logisticians transport Water from Cisterns, Water Towers, Wells, Rainwater Collectors and Electric Pumps in the settlement to the Water Point. The Water can be drunk by Settlers here. The Water Point can be instructed to take out Water only from certain Buildings.

The Factory Unit <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Engineers. The Production speed at <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Tailor's Shops</style></link>, <link="12"><style="DefaultLink">Workshops</style></link>, <link="23"><style="DefaultLink">Ammunition Factories</style></link>, <link="9"><style="DefaultLink">Medical Facilities</style></link> and <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Decontamination Posts</style></link> located in the vicinity of the Factory Unit is increased by the presence of the Factory Unit. The Factory Unit continuously consumes <link="25"><style="DefaultLink">Reinforced Metal</style></link>, <link="25"><style="DefaultLink">Concrete</style></link> and <link="25"><style="DefaultLink">Glass</style></link>. To be able to build a Factory Unit the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first. The Factory Unit reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers whose <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> is nearby.
Factory Unit
Research
Research
Knowledge
Research Utensils
Research can be performed to develop new <link="1"><style="DefaultLink">Buildings</style></link>, formulas or other technologies for a settlement.
Knowledge is needed to perform Research. It is either generated by Researchers at the Research Station or found on <link="14"><style="DefaultLink">Expeditions</style></link>.

The Research Station <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Researchers. Research can be performed at the Research Station. If no Research is being performed, all Researchers employed at the Research Station generate Knowledge. The Research Station reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity.

Research utensils can be found on <link="14"><style="DefaultLink">Expeditions</style></link>. Some types of Research require Research utensils. The more Research utensils accumulated, the more the types of Research that become accessible. These Research utensils are not used up during Research.
Decorations
Decorations

Decorations can be used to design the residential areas of the settlement more attractively for the Settlers. Decorations increase the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers with a <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in the area's sphere of influence.
Shrubs can be placed to slightly increase the attractiveness of an area.
Flower Beds can be placed to slightly increase the attractiveness of an area.
Torches can be placed to slightly increase the attractiveness of an area.
A Scrap Totem can be placed to sharply increase the attractiveness of an area.
Wind Chimes can be placed to increase the attractiveness of an area.
Hedges can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Flags can be placed to slightly increase the Attractiveness of an area.

The Pioneer Statue can be placed to sharply increase the Attractiveness of an area. Settlers can visit the Pioneer Statue in order to increase their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>.
The Pergola can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area very sharply. Settlers can visit the Pergola in order to increase their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>.
The Memorial can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area very sharply. Settlers can visit the Memorial in order to increase their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>.
Streetlamps can be placed to slightly increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Decrees
The Bulletin Board
Decrees
The Bulletin Board stands mounted at the Forum. Settlers accumulate matters that concern them here. From time to time it ought to be checked whether a new request has been hung on the Bulletin Board.

Decrees can be issued at the Forum that Settlers are going to comply with. Each Decree has both advantages and disadvantages for the settlement. While issuing Decrees, however, too much should never be imposed on Settlers. Up to two Decrees can be active at the same time. To be able to issue some of the Decrees corresponding <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.
The Forum allows access to the Bulletin Board along with the possibility to issue Decrees.
Barter Trade Deal
Closing a Barter Trade Deal
Trader
Trader Reputation
Improved Radio Mast

A Barter Trade Deal can be closed with a Trader whenever a Trader pays a visit to the settlement. Resources the Trader wants to have can be bartered for Resources the Trader has brought with them. To attract a Trader to the settlement a Trading Post must already exist.

The Trading Post <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> <link="18"><style="DefaultLink">Logisticians</style></link>. From time to time Traders from other settlements are going to pay a visit to the Trading Post and barter with the settlement. Once a Barter Trade Deal has been closed the Logisticians begin to transport the Resources destined for the Trader to the Trading Post.

A Trader always carries only a certain number of Resources with them. At the same time, the Trader is only interested in certain Resources, too. As the first step a Barter Trade Deal is always proposed to the Trader. This Offer specifies which Resources from the Settlement are supposed to be bartered in return for which Resources from the Trader. The proposed Barter Trade Deal shouldn't be too unfair, otherwise the Trader will reject the Offer.

Provided a Trader has already previously visited a settlement, each Trader has a personal opinion of that settlement. The better this Reputation is, the more likely it will be that a Trader offers to barter special Resources like Seeds or Knowledge. Some of the Traders also offer to barter <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Animals</style></link> when the Trader has a high opinion of the settlement. A Trader who has a high opinion of the settlement will also accept an Offer they would reject under normal circumstances. In turn, a Trader who doesn't have a good word to say about the settlement will reject an Offer faster than the Trader normally would have accepted.

Which Trader is going to pay a visit to the settlement as next on their list can be seen at the Trading Post. Once an improved radio mast has been <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">researched</style></link>, which Trader should be the next to arrive can be configured manually.
User Interface
Raiders
Raiders
Tribute
Sulfur
Metal Projectiles
Rubber Bullets

Every now and then it might happen that Raiders cast an eye on the settlement. If they decide to attack, Watchtowers, Siren Towers or Barricades can be used to defend the settlement. A gang of Raiders will make their way across the settlement and loot Resources from all the Buildings in their vicinity. In the process, all Buildings within this radius will be damaged as well. The Raiders won't withdraw until they have either looted enough Resources or their Morale has decreased too sharply. If the Militia shoots Metal Projectiles at the Raiders this will reduce their Force Strength. If the Militia shoots using Rubber Bullets this lowers the Raiders' Morale.
Raiders often demand Tribute before they decide to attack. If the settlement is willing and able to raise this amount of Tribute, the Raiders will refrain from attacking this time.

Sulfur can be mined in <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Mines</style></link> and is needed during the Production of Metal Projectiles and Rubber Bullets. To be able to mine Sulfur in Mines the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

Metal Projectiles can be used by Militia stationed in a Watchtower to fire at attacking Raiders. When doing so, each shot fired reduces the Force Strength of a horde of Raiders. Metal Projectiles are manufactured at the Ammunition Factory and consist of Sulfur, <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link> and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Metal</style></link>.

Rubber Bullets can be used by Militia stationed in a Watchtower to fire at attacking Raiders. When doing so, each shot fired reduces the Morale of a horde of Raiders. Rubber Bullets are manufactured at the Ammunition Factory and consist of Sulfur, <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link> and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Plastic</style></link>.

The Ammunition Factory <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Technicians. Technicians manufacture Metal Projectiles and Rubber Bullets out of Sulfur, <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link> and <link="16"><style="DefaultLink">Metal or Plastic</style></link>. Which product ought to be produced next can be set. The employed Technician begins with work on the new product as soon as the current Task has been completed. The Ammunition Factory reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> in its vicinity. To be able to build an Ammunition Factory the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

The Watchtower <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Militia. The Militia stationed there fires at attacking Raiders from the tower. To do this they need either Metal Projectiles or Rubber Bullets. Which type of Ammunition is supposed to be used can be configured on the Watchtower at any time. The Watchtower uses up more Ammunition <link="7"><style="DefaultLink">at night</style></link> than during the daytime. This disadvantage can be compensated for when the Watchtower is connected to a functioning <link="13"><style="DefaultLink">Power Grid</style></link>. To be able to build a Watchtower the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> has to be performed first.

The Siren Tower lowers the Morale of Raiders located within its range as long as it is supplied with <link="13"><style="DefaultLink">Electricity</style></link>. To be able to build a Siren Tower the corresponding <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.

The Barricade reduces the speed of movement of all Raiders located in its surrounding area. To be able to set up a Barricade the corresponding <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first.
Demands
Demands

Settlers are going to make demands at the Town Hall toward improving their living conditions. When doing so there will always be two suggestions, whereby one of the Demands has to be fulfilled. Unlike what happens at the <link="21"><style="DefaultLink">Forum</style></link>, the Settlers’ <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> drops severely when their demands are not being fulfilled or the Demands are ignored.
Demands

The Town Hall is the highest upgrade level for the <link="18"><style="DefaultLink">Town Center</style></link>. The Town Hall can store any Resource except <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>. The type of Resource which is supposed to be stored at the Town Hall can be configured at any time. What’s more, the Town Hall serves as the place to go for Settlers to make Demands regarding life at the settlement. The Town Hall cannot be built until your Settlers express the wish to have it built. They will not express this wish until a certain number of <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research Projects</style></link> have been researched first.
Population Growth

The growth indicator shows how far your settlement is on the way to becoming a real metropolis. The more Settlers your settlement contains and the farther your Beacon has been upgraded, the closer you will get to this goal. Once the Beacon landmark has been fully upgraded you will have created a metropolis that can stand the test of time.
The Beacon

The Beacon can be upgraded up to two times. The last upgrade level greatly increases the Attractiveness of your entire settlement. How far you can upgrade your Beacon landmark depends on the number of Settlers you have.
Augmented Construction Materials
Concrete

Concrete is produced at a Concrete Factory out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Sand</style></link>, <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>, <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link> and <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Cement</style></link>. Concrete is needed as construction material for many sturdy Buildings.
Concrete Factory

The Concrete Factory <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Engineers. Concrete is produced at a Concrete Factory out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Sand</style></link>, <link="6"><style="DefaultLink">Water</style></link>, <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link> and <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Cement</style></link>. Concrete is needed as construction material for many sturdy Buildings. To be able to build a Concrete Factory the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first. The Concrete Factory reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers whose <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">dwelling</style></link> is nearby.
Glass

Glass is manufactured at a Material Factory out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Sand</style></link> and <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link>. Glass serves as construction material for Buildings like the <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Aquafarm</style></link> or the <link="5"><style="DefaultLink">Greenhouse</style></link>.
Strengthened Metal

Strengthened Metal is manufactured at a Material Factory out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Metal</style></link> and <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link>. Strengthened Metal is needed as construction material for many sturdy Buildings.
Material Factory

The Material Factory <link="3"><style="DefaultLink">employs</style></link> Recyclers. Glass can be manufactured at the Material Factory out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Sand</style></link> and <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link>, and Strengthened Metal out of <link="15"><style="DefaultLink">Metal</style></link> and <link="11"><style="DefaultLink">Coal</style></link>. To be able to build a Material Factory the appropriate <link="19"><style="DefaultLink">Research</style></link> must be performed first. The Material Factory reduces the <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Contentedness</style></link> of all Settlers who have their <link="4"><style="DefaultLink">Residence</style></link> nearby.

Benches can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Modern Lamps can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Monuments can be placed to greatly increase the Attractiveness of an area.
The "Pavilion" can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area very sharply. Settlers can visit the Pavilion to boost their <link="8"><style="DefaultLink">Confidence</style></link>.
Standing Torches can be placed to slightly increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Flower Monuments can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Cages can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Cauldrons can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Dark Flags can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Fire Pits can be placed to greatly increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Grim Reapers can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Memorials to the Dead can be placed to greatly increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Pumpkins can be placed to slightly increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Scarecrows can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Skull Torches can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Totems can be placed to greatly increase the Attractiveness of an area.
The Great Old One can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Gargoyle Statues can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
Hanging Cages can be placed to increase the Attractiveness of an area.
